lu.dd: tune, good tune; patia'len-a'len: to sing a good tune
(Ind.) custom, tradition
to take; to borrow; to touch; to begin; pangala badong: leader of the badong round dance
ricebarn
crested hornbill [Aceros cassidix]
mortar
ritual, rites, rule of the ancestors; mangaluk: to call the divinities to perform the ritual; pangalukan: ritual; aluk simuane tallang ‘rites paired like bamboos’.
our rule, our ritual
mango (tree and fruit) [Mangifera spp.]
father, leading man; pa'amberan uncle; ambe' tondok chief of the village; ambe' saroan chief of a mutual organisation
water shoot [Caladium speciosa]
fig-tree [Ficus ampelas]
sister, maiden ; effigy inside the house during bua' kasalle (see tumba')
(in the Pangngala' area) social status of third rank among those who perform
fragrant grass in the mountain; G.sp. unknown
(Mamasa area) solo male song with plucked-boat lute (katapi), formerly accompanied by the zither (tandilo).
bamboo [Dendrocalamus strictus]
golden bamboo; G.sp. unknown
breast, heart
mythic animal, bird
head hunting clamor
dog [Canis Lupus]
large family of language spoken in Taiwan, Malagasy, South Vietnam, the Malay peninsula, Borneo, Indonesia, Philippines, Micronesia, Melanesia, Polynesia.
(=ba'tang) stomach, heart, thought
parrot (gen.) [Psittacidae]
funeral round dance, sung by a male chorus
pig [Sus scrofa]
decorated basket (often used to carry vegetables)
high platform on which meat is distributed at funerals
stranger, Dutchman, white man
fish
cockroach
pair, double; answer; adversary; membali: to reverse, to return
to come back, to turn around
amulet
hoopoe, woodpecker [Upupa epops]
funerary ceremonial mast (for the highest funerals)
k.o. bamboo rattle (archaic); clapper bell (used for the manganda’ dance or the singgi' eulogy at the bua' kasalle celebration)
ginger [Acorus calamus]
pineapple fibre
house
banyan [Ficus religiosa, ficus benjamini]; (fig.) high nobleman
(Bonggakaradeng area) sung by women when bringing coffee to guests at funerals, in return for money
head hunter; courageous
nice, small
rice
sun disk with rays ; k.o. carving pattern ; attribute of noble men
aerophone; sibarrung: to be paired to sound together; pasibarrung: to play together; sauan sibarrung: double bellow used for the forge, two long tubes which are activated in alternation
double clarinet (see tulali) (=basin, basin-basin, basing-pasing)
oath, pledge, promise; passage, vowel, change; hanging down on both sides
iron
ceremonial mast
lamentation
chorus song with drone, usually sung standing up (Saluputti area); see dandan
cockatoo; G.sp. unknown)
vocal embellishment in the simbong song
melody sung while jumping during the maro ritual
k.o. bird with white and grey feathers; G.sp. unknown
tree whose fruits replace the areca nut; G.sp. unknown
serpent fish; G.sp. Unknown
k.o. Reed [Miscanthus japonicaus]
k.o. Fish; G.sp. unknown

game of divination to check for one's misdeeds (mendaka salanna) (the to minaa officiant takes his sticks, releases them, then separates them into two groups, throw them down and counts the number of sticks in one group by twos. If the number is odd, it is a sign that a fault has been committed
ritual speech
plant that grows in the forest (passion fruit?) [Passiflora quadrangulis ?]
betel (liana), fruit of the liana [Piper betle]
shade of a deceased person, image, phantom emerging from the human body after death, wandering without receptacle (the tau-tau effigies are called bombo dikita “shades that are seen”)
healing ritual with a flute accompaniment (suling bonde) in Mamasa and Simbuang areas
white water buffalo [Bubalus bubalis]
k.o. Plant with violet flowers and small deep red round fruit, opening only when ripe; G.sp. Unknown
peaceful dove; spotted turtle-dove [Streptopelia chinensis tigrina, Geopelia striata]
generic term for all kind of fruits

group of villages, formerly a ritual unit which performed a bua' ritual together ; ritual from the side of the rising sun; bua' kasalle: highest ritual on the side of the rising sun, syn. la'pa', penanian
casuarina [Casuarina equisetifolia]
bamboo slats covering laid over the ridge of a house

bean; in the rising sun rituals, lyrics of the songs; tae' bang buena 'we don't understand the lyrics'; tae' bang ma'bue dirangi tu kadanna 'we cannot hear the meaning of the lyrics'; pokada ri buena 'tell us the lyrics'; see kadong
mixed-sex chorus ; dance ; illness ; curing ; prophylactic rite with trances.
bone; buku suling ‘flute bone’, fundamental piece in the suling deata performance at the healing pakorong ritual
Gold ; (fig.) nobility
ma'bulle: to hold someone or something together in palanquin; bullean: palanquin
fresh-water crab, crab (generic)
female or male officiant of rituals on the side of the rising sun
bird, often found in ricefields; G.sp. Unknown
to blow, to snort
upstream
mango tree and fruit [Mangifera spp.]
chameleon; G.sp. Unknown
k.o. Banyan [Ficus sp. Unknown]
(Makassarese) oldest brother
maize, corn [Zea mays]
destiny
vague sound
damar, resin, white damar, Indian agathis [Agathis alba]
guava [Eugenia jambolana]
to be in a line ; women’s chorus in a line, with two vocal parts, using drone, used in bua' padang, merok, and bua' kasalle celebrations; see nani
ancestral model
gladiolus; G.sp. Unknown
cotton; G.sp. Unknown
small bird that likes to drink wine palm; G.sp. Unknown
k.o. rice without husk; G.sp. Unknown
Austronesian noble title; lord, king, queen, princess (Datu may be used for gods, noble men or noble women).

god, goddess, divinity, spirit; (in contrast to puang and datu, the deata, generally unnamed, are only to be found in the sphere of the gods); to ma'deata 'the one who does divinity' is the person who goes into trance during maro and bugi'; nene' mendeata: ancestors sharing the essence and qualities of the divinities
to beat the drum
sparrow; grey wagtail [Motacilla cinerea melanope]
Pity ! Poor thing !
over there ; the setting sun
downward
from ganna' ‘complete’; in dondi' or badong songs, pegs and crutches, words without meaning to fill the melodyas for example 'le', 'ala tello tello'
from kalando ‘long’; to hold a pitch at the end of a musical pattern (antonym: dipatorro)
from torro ‘to stay’; to stop a musical sentence (antonym: dipakalando)
from rapa' ‘still’; stretched out; a death ritual of the highest order
up, high; dipamadao gamaranna ‘the voices have risen’
gold leaf; (fig.) high noble women in badong song
funerary stanzas sung at night (syn. Londe, sengo) in mixed-sex chorus with one or two vocal parts ; (Mamasa area) polyphonic songs sung while weeding paddy fields to enhance their fertility
(Saluputti area) female chorus with two vocale lines and drone, sung while seated (see dandan)
bamboo fork clapper for pakorong healing ritual
water buffalo with white head and white back [Bubalus bubalis]
water buffalo with a white spot on its head [Bubalus bubalis]
durian [Durio zibethinus]

(bua' kasalle ritual) word used at start of every line in song when girls descend from the banyan tree, (Makki region) k. o. dance with women in a line singing and dancing in front of the ladder used by the girls to climb up the tree
(badong song) to insert additional pitches into the unison line sung by the chorus
ladder
very old wooden coffin, carved in the shape of a ship or a house, reserved for nobility
(=kerra) snoring (for pigs)
foot bracelet
voice; gamara melo ‘fine voice’; gamara pada-pada: united voices; angku menggamara pindan ‘for my voice sounds like a plate’ (in maro song); ma'gamarai ‘to sing’
gambir [Uncariae ramulus, uncus]

double-headed cylindrical drum; (fig.) traditional specialist of ritual speech; to ma'gandang ‘the one who hits the drum'; gandang pamelongan: assistant of the burake at the bua' kasalle ritual; tae' pa digandangi: ‘he has not yet been drummed’ [the eastern rituals have not yet been performed for him]
(=garissing, gumarissing) (re voice) metallic
two-headed pellet hand drum made from python skin; exclusive attribute of the to burake, officiant on the side of the rising sun (=garatung, garapung, karatung, karatu, gamaru)
(=karente) chirruping, chirping, bird song; quivering, vibrant sound, staccato but pleasant to hear; ma'garente: to vibrate, tremble, shiver
golden kris; gayang pirri': thick kris (fig.) bravery
Young girls' dance in maro ritual inspired by the pursuit of a sparrow, with gestures named after birds
rhythmically chanted narratives in maro and bugi’ trance rituals; ma'kelong: to sing the gelong; k. o. gelong: gelong kandeatan; gelong ma’pasae deata; gelong unnondo
one- or two-stringed fiddle, made from the sugar palm (induk), played at funerals to accompany the marakka song, or in trio in healing pakorong ritual
pellet bells; bells
bamboo fork clapper; (Mandar area) gongga' lima (hand's jewsharp); (Majene area) jarumbing; see dongga and karombi
the sitting crier; from gora 'glottis' and tongkon 'to sit'; (Pangngala' area) first class, famous people, from high nobility (equivalent to the Puang in the South Toraja).
raised wooden platform used for ceremonial purposes at the bua' kasalle ritual; gorang bulaan 'golden platform'; see bala'kaan
soul, spirit, mind, heart, thought

mother, leader, indo’ gelong; indo’ badong; indo’ simbong are leaders of musical groups; indo'i: to be responsible, indo'i: to fork, go out of the way; mangindo'i: to beat the drum in alternation (one on the off-beat, the other on the beat)
(Ind.) generation of a national Indonesian culture
sugar palm; areng [Arenga pinnata, Arenga saccharifera]
(Mamasa area) polyphonic songs sung while weeding paddy fields to enhance their fertility (syn. dondi’)
rectangular wooden trough (issong pandan) or rounded stone basin (issong batu); sangissong badong: a circle of badong singers
(Sa'dan area) male round dance with unison singing, performed during house ceremony (merok)
young women's dance, accompanied by singing to welcome guests to funerals
word; ma'kada 'to tell'; ma'kada buntu 'secret speech'
seed ; kadong badong: lyrics to the badong song (syn. Bating)
ma' kadongi: to fix bundles to a bamboo; (fig.) to add extra lines in the badong song ; to ma'kadongi: the one who shouts the badong song lyrics
crow; G.sp. Unknown
plant with red fruit; G.sp. Unknown
speech for the deceased, at the beginning of the highest funerals, before the sacrifices
(from la'pa' ‘free’) ceremonial field for the Eastern rituals; last stage of large eastern rituals held on the kala'paran field
setting sun (syn. dio)
(Mamasa area) quatrains sung to various melodies, s.t. accompanied by flute or plucked lute (first and third lines octosyllabic second and fourth lines heptasyllabic)
dikallae: alas
black bird with red brown back; G.sp. Unknown
betel nut palm, betel nut [Areca catechu]
redeeming errors or personal misdeeds (pengkalossoran) (syn. massuru')
coconut tree [Cocos nucifera]
name of a place located in the north of the Toraja country, famous for its weavings

waterfall swift, white-throated needletail, silver-backed needletail, giant swiftlet; giant Asian swift; palm swift; chimney swallow; red-rumped swallow; salangane [Collocalia gigas, Hirundapus caudacutus cochenchinensis]
Numerous ; to kamban ‘ordinary people’; (Pangngala' area) the lowest class (south from Rantepao= kaunan)
k.o. tree with large leaves; G.sp. unknown; shaded area; kambuno langi' (‘heaven's shade’)= ancestor of the to minaa
an ornament fashioned from beads, used in ceremonies
taken by a divinity, in trance
(Sidenreng Rappang area) title of a famous song sung and accompanied by a fiddle
(Makassarese) honorific title for a prince
cotton; penalty paid by husband or wife who commits adultery (see rampanan kapa')
generic term for water buffalo [Bubalus bubalis]
jew's harp
eulogy at the bua' kasalle celebration
(archaic) drum
sad, melancholic; in the badong, the master of song is called indo' karorrong ('mother of sorrow'); ma' karorrongan: ‘to sing in a melancholic way while remembering old memories’
riddle
rafter
two stringed boat lute (archaic su'dekan)
dance performed by twelve women, accompanied by two flute, to welcome guests to funerals
house carving in the form of a big, long-necked bird with a crest on top of its head, either a cock or a mythical bird of the forests.
Indian Galangal [Alpinia galanga]
slave
tree (generic)
cotton; tikembong: to swell, to make waves
to go up, to rise; dipakendek tu gamara ‘this voice has gone in the upper register’
k. o. small edible mushroom; G.sp. unknown
k. o. small red and yellow breasted bird; G.sp. unknown
high creaking sound; antonym dipamurru
ma'kirrokan: rubbing and creaking sound used in vocal embellishments for badong song (see garete, korok)
frog (generic)
to dance landing on one foot then the other
to work alternately; sikore-kore: sounds to be heard in alternation (e.g. rice being husked by several people)

sound of hen calling her chicks; to call to assemble; pa’korok: the one who directs, who calls; (simbong song) the one who sings above or below the others; dikorok: song in which one or more soloists sing lines other than that sung in unison
little egret; Chinese pond heron [Ardeola bacchus ; Egretta garzetta]
two holed-flute
forest bird (generic)
to sing the gelong song
(from kombong ‘to create, to make’), to kumombongta ‘our creator’
sound kung; ma'kungkung ‘to be full of sound’
sound for calling chickens; ma'kurre: speech performed by the burake at the bua' kasalle (syn. ma'tambuli)
in daily life: thank you; the name of some Christian celebrations, kind of thanksgiving; in ritual speech ‘come back, vital energy’
k. o. marsupial, kuskus; couscous [Ailurops ursinus]
clapper for scaring off birds
free, finished; last stage of Eastern ceremonies like la'pa' bua', la'pa' bugi', la'pa' maro, la'pa' gandang; bua' kasalle ritual (=la'pa' kasalle = la'pa' banua = bua' sangrapu)
to be pushed out, to escape, to keep singing when the others have stoped ; la'pu tu sangmuaneku lan badong ‘in the badong, my friend made a mistake’
(merok and bua' kasalle ceremonies) bamboo bench sanctified by animal sacrifices, on which female nani singers seat
Bugis language epics, probably dating from thirteenth to fifteenth centuries
(from telai, telek ‘vulva’) indicates female gender (e.g., Lai' Tasik Princess of the seas (similarly So', from laso ‘penis' indicates male gender)
tower on funerary ceremonial field containing remains of the deceased; lakkean sura' carved tower
path, road
(fighting) quail [Turnix suscitator atrogularis] ; melale': to laugh.
(north of Toraja country, around Pangngala') aerophon (syn. Pelle')
crested hornbill [Aceros cassidix] (=alo)
k. o. banyan; G.sp. unknown
soft (antonym karra)
buried, planted underground; (voice) low and muffled.
Inside ; east, side of the rising sun
sky
birds of prey (generic) e.g., falcon, hawk, kite, vulture, sparrowhawk etc.
lansium tree [Lansium domesticum]
hut, shed
bloodwort [Cordyline terminalis]
garlic [Allium sativum]
over there, downwards (=lo', lao')
step of a ladder: aluk silau' eran rule of the graduated ladder
(houses) noble, principal
to twist and turn when running; (simbong song) describes soloist's embellishments; ma'lekko tarru ‘to make embellishments continuously ; na lekko tongan tu gamaranna his voice twists and turns
inverted; bandera leko': inverted mast
lullaby (syn. Teinde)
Malemba' (words) clear, distinct; ma'lemba' tama talingangku it came clearly into my ears
boat ; customary territory, adat community ; subdistrict (*kecamatan)
lemon tree, grapefruit tree [Citrus maxima, Citrus medica, Citrus nobilis...]
small, thin eel [Monopterus albus]
Indian Galangal [Alpinia galanga]
to roll along; to repeat a word in order to be listened to: manglenten: to state clearly lyrics of badong song before they are sung; penglenten: lines to be pronounced before being sung
A circle ; complete, united; malepong gamaranna ‘his voice is round’
clear
rock grave
(myth) name of a small island (also named Pongko')
ma'lili-lili: to squeal like a hungry pig
cicada, cricket, grasshopper, field grasshopper; G.sp. Unknown
from all sides; badong limbu or badong dilimbui: homophonic round dance in which everyone sings (syn. badong lembang, badong dimintui; (antonym) badong ditetuk badong with corners
a rice stalk (syn. pelle)
downriver
golden hairbun
praising song, lullaby
top; diloloki: to complete a ritual cycle by reaching the 'top of the ritual ladder'
kind of pantun, spoken or sung by two or more singers; see dondi’
rooster, cock [Gallus gallus domesticus]
overhanging sections of roof at each end of the house
join together, answer; see aluk silopak tallang
water buffalo with black back [Bubalus bubalis]
dance motion of the bugi'
title for a man in the bua' kasalle ceremony
(lit.) mast of heaven; immense bamboo at bua' kasalle ceremony, linking officiants at end of the ladder to heavens
kingdom of South Sulawesi
one of the concluding rites for the dead when coffins reopened, shrouds changed, offering made to ancestors
wide ceremonial rectangles of cloth in varying sizes, imported from India via Java
(from kaka ‘elder’); to makaka: people of middle nobility
hot, feverish
oily, soft (voices in badong song)
sky people; someone who goes into trance; (in gelong maro song, usually paired with tumbang)
to miss someone or something which is far away; [Toraja do not have a single word for love, except mamali’]
to hold someone or something on a palanquin
clever (syn. pande)
k. o. rice, with tassle ; G.sp. Unknown
calling divinities (deata); mangaluk to tumbang: ritual for the tumbang woman at the bua' kasalle celebration.
dance in second part of bua’ kasalle ceremony, in which men wear large, heavy horned helmets shake bells and shout
prophylactic ritual against smallpox; see pakorong
a war cry
to hunt a human head
ritual for the ancestors, see nene'
to pray
from indo' ‘mother’; mangindo'i: to beat the drum in alternation (one on the off-beat, the other on the beat)
to jump
to anoint the house with blood : ceremony performed on rebuilding origin house
bead
(chorus with drone) to sing simbong at bua' kasalle ceremony, see simbong
to play
to kill with a spear
scarring the skin
cock, hen, chicken [Gallus gallus domesticus]; manuk-manuk: generic term for fowls
wasp; G.sp. Unknown
noisy, loud and high voice; marakase maro tu dondinna ‘this dondi' is far too loud’
song sung by one to three women accompanied by one or more flautists, for arrival of guests at funerals for noble men or women
melancholy (see rio, bating, karorrong)
ritual involving bodily mutilations (mantere) and trance following frenzied dances; maro-maro 'idiot, simple'; Puang Maro: ancestor of the chicken, god of frenzy
loud, to have fun together, to laugh together; (about a chorus): too noisy, not well balanced
(Mamasa area) soloist singing above or under the drone in the simbong and io-io songs (= Toraja Sa'dan indo' simbong)
see sampa'
big eel [Anguilla australis]
(from sarapa wash, purify by eliminating dirt), song chanted at the bua' kasalle, describing the expulsion of terrestrial illnesses
(from sebok, sabok when a glass is full, to throw out a little bit), metaphor for the toraja ceremonies, to share when a glass flows over
(from suru' comb)chicken sacrificed to ancestors as simple rite of atonement, rite of cleansing; see sara’ka
to wrap up; to mebalun : the one who wraps up the body
nice, beautiful, fine
to praise ; menani: to sing in a chorus at the bua' kasalle celebration ; to menani: male officiant who performs an eulogy (see dondo, simbong, dandan)
to praise the rice (syn. bua' sang bongi' )
(from rok 'to kill with a spear') one of the highest ritual on the side of the rising sun, before the bua' kasalle celebration (= tokonan tedong ‘to spear the buffalo’)
knowledge; to minaa ‘one who knows’
memongan, to blow up, sound of a tree falling
boy, man, husband
wild duck; whistling teal; pelican; widgeon [Dendrocygna javanica]
jackfruit [Artocarpus heterophyllus]
see menani
grandfather, grandmother, deified ancestor; ma'nene': one of the concluding rites for the dead, with the opening of the graves
motion of legs in any kind of dance (ondo badong, ondo maro, ondo bugi' etc.); usually refers to trance dance at maro or bugi' celebrations
anoa (of Sulawesi) [Bubulus quarlesi anoa depressicornis]
see nondo
sound (of human, animal or instrument); sala' oni ‘out of tune’
(from tono': compose with levels, from the smallest to the largest); mangono': to construct like a roof by piling bamboos in order of size; badong diono': badong song arranged with groups of soloists
female chorus at eastern ceremonies, sometimes synonym with retteng; siore': alternated chanting
loud sound (when a buffalo is killed, when an old person cries); the divinity Indo' Orron, yelling all the time, transformed herself in pig
long narrative arranged in lines
base, root (=to')
alas
pity
title of a joge' song
helper, functionary in a village
gong; group of gongs, played during the reception of guests in funerals (syn. Bombongan)
earth, field
scarlet ixora [Ixora coccinea]
healing ritual against smallpox ; ma'pakorong: to perform this healing ritual
fern [Diplazium proliferum]

cowlicks; circular patterns in human and animal body parts (e.g., fingerprint, scalp, earlobe) [Humans have palisu on the tips of their fingers and at the centre of their scalps. Buffaloes have six cowlicks. The position and number of cowlicks determine the quality of an animal.
castorbean [Ricinus communis]
monkey; G.sp. Unknown
(from belong 'to ask this and that'), gandang pamelongan 'demanding drum', name of an officiant at the bua' kasalle, who sings and asks this and that
(from ala ‘to take’), pangala is the one who begins to sing; pangala gelong, pangala badong
k. o. soft and fragrant grass, in the mountain; G.sp. unknown

betel quid; Torajan betel quid includes several ingredients: betel leaf (Piper betel, toraja daun bolu), betel fruit (toraja bolu bua’), areca nut (Areca catechu; toraja kalosi), and lime powder (toraja kapu’)
(from ria ‘carrying on one's knees’), title for some women at the bua' kasalle ceremony
see pelle'
each one separately, pantan ma'badong: to sing the badong song separately but at the same time
the one who shouts the line of lamentation during the badong song (syn. pantolo' bating)
mango tree [Mangifera spp.]
triangular gable
support; paradangan ada': individual responsible for customary practices
unhusked rice (before and after harvest)
market; ma' pasa' (lit. to go to the market) names last day of eastern rituals like maro, bugi' and bua' kasalle when people enter in exchange with divinities
plant with red flowers and conical fruits with soothing effect; G.sp. Unknown; ma'passake: opening or ending song, asking favors
narrative describing path of ritual rule (melalan aluk) ; speech to divinities at bua' kasalle, performed by two officiants in alternation
(lit. , to venerate the buffalo) praise of buffalo chanted at merok ceremony
purifying ritual with tagari plant ; see tagari
from both sides
k.o. Of thick bamboo [Dendrocalamus asper ; Bambusa vulgaris ? ]
towards; sipatu: same direction, same aim; kasipatuan: in harmony, in agreement; napasipatu tu tang sipatunna ‘he combines what should not be combined'
slow; dipela: to slow down a musical piece.

aerophon from rice stalk split in several places [this stalk serves as the reed (a rare case of a multiple reed); it is introduced into a funnel-shaped sugar palm leaf resonator] (syn. barrung, oni-oni, poni-poni, panoni, tamorron, lullio, liuk-liuk)
prohibition
reversal
(lit., place of the song) customary area ; bua' or la'pa' ceremony
to compensate for ritual errors
offering placed on stacked pieces of banana leaf [Bloodwort-leaf may also be used in bua' kasalle and maro rituals]
(from tuo life) petuo : (lit., supporters of life) central house posts supporting roof
to show, to indicate
(from turo to go to) tree hung with pieces of meat for divinities planted at center of yard in front of house during bua' kasalle
flowers (generic)
bowl, plate in stone, white
loin cloth
segment of bamboo in which food is cooked
bitter-tasting climbing plant (grows in earth or water) ; G.sp. unknown
(Saluputti area) song sung in older times during bua' ceremony (probably similar to bugi' song)
monophonic bamboo trumpets and/or orchestra of bamboo trumpets and bamboo flutes (= musik bambu, bas musik, pa'bas)
pineapple [Ananas comosus]
(from pirik-pirik: to turn; windmill used as bird-scarer ) divinity of rain, ancestor of rain
see pelle'
god, lord, prince; title of nobility; ma'puang: see pakorong
black buffalo [Bubalus bubalis]
Lit., finding death at the same moment, first day, first part of the highest funerals.
‘to gather in order to speak together’; rite from second part of bua' kasalle, when officiants pray all night, alternating with each other
banana tree [Musa spp.]
mythical plain where ladder linked heaven and earth (realm of the dead where 'shades' of the deceased said to go, located between Kalosi and Enrekang
nearly at the same pitch, nearly the same : ra'da' simbong: soloist’s embellishments in simbong song
plants growing in stony soil; G.sp. Unknown
(from ra'ban: to begin at the same time) in badong song, when chorus sings again after soloist
smoke; rambu tuka' smoke that rises; rambu solo' smoke that descends (naming the two parts of the ritual cycle)

(from rampan: go towards, descend towards); rampanan kapa' metaphor for marriage; from kapa' ‘cotton, fine’ to be paid for breaking the agreement’. In general, in a case of separation, the party to the contract must give one or more buffaloes to his partner; the debt varies depending on the social class
side; rampe matampu' 'on the side of the setting sun', rampe matallo 'on the side of the rising sun'
affines
a badong song resembling a song from eastern sphere, as the bugi', sung in Randan Batu, Balik and Sangngalla'
male war dance for welcoming guests to most elaborate funerals
to listen to
(Ind.) many layers
marsh plant, water plant; G.sp. Unknown
sacrificial field where concluding phase funeral rites celebrated; rante kala'paran: ritual ground for bua' kasalle ceremony
resting place, hollowed out tree trunk, shaped like rice-stamping block, in which deceased placed on completion of first death feast (Veen 1966:32); highest funerals for nobility
ornementation, embellishment
twinsuling rapi' : (Mamasa and Rantepao) flute with two tubes [One tube has five holes; the second has none.]
cognatic descent group claiming a common ancestor
blood
necklace consisting of three gold-covered wooden cylinders; (fig.) high noblewomen
to dance bending one's knee
cutting a leaf to determine ritual error causing a problem
upriver
mareko: noisy
to spread ;mangrenden : to sing the drone in simbong song
to lead the buffalo at funerals
ornaments for the lyrics
tight (about cloth), squeezed, compact, close-by; trills on flute, mangrepe': to play trills
(Central Sulawesi) bamboo fork
freely composed eulogy or satire declaimed during great simbong, nani or badong choruses
carrying on one's knees; naria aluk: held by ritual deeds
noisy, loud, strong (=mariak, rumeak)
sadness
to sing apart from the unison; na ma'roganni lan tu pa'tindokan: he adds variations to the chorus’s vocal line
noisy, loud

to resound continuously; tang didedek anna roreng 'we do not strike it and it resounds'; ma'roreng-roreng tongan tu dondinna: a very good dondi' song with a continous and full sound; roreng-rorengmo langi' 'the sky rumbles'
very clear (about voice); tang marorrongan ‘unclear’ (voice out of tune)
(from bengan: to give) rumengan-mengan oninna: a nice sound

sound, voice, song, tune; tae' diissan sa'dana: we don't know the tune; messa'da: to put in sound; to cough to have a better voice (the speaker does that in order to find the line to perform); angku messa'da bombongan (gelong) ‘so that I sound like a gong’
golden headgear worn by the noble women
Gecko [Hemidactylus frenatus]
Python ; G.sp. unknown
dance for the reception of guests: two flute players and twelve female dancers in a line
pure water
fault
white water buffalo [Bubalus bubalis]
river ; good path ; telling the good way
happiness, fecundity; (fig.) bua' kasalle ritual
water buffalo with black and grey head [Bubalus bubalis]
narrative segment [the samparan simbong is composed of sampa' kake'deran ‘narrative of the departure’, sampa' lalan ‘narrative of the road’, and sampa’ tongkonan ‘narrative of the house’
narrative given by one or more officiants (to minaa), sometimes supported by singers, before the sacrifices. Ex: samparan tedong, samparan buru', samparan bugi', samparan bate', samparan simbong
(in badong song) highest leader
other side
to name
all together
ancestral model
(rice) bundle of five ; five songs sung alternatively by different groups of singers in badong round dance
tube zither or stick zither
(from sape: to collect, pluck the leaves from a stem); sapean tabang: pick the leaves off the cordyline plant, (fig.) maro ritual in which the cordyline plant (tabang) plays a predominant role
comb used in loom; look for dirt and fleas in the hair’; atonement rite (syn. Suru’)
waterfall
stretcher, bier in the form of a Toraja house
rainbow
narrow, long fabric, often blue and white, used at both Eastern and Western rituals [imported sarita are from Dutch origin]
mutual aid organization in a village, for ritual or agricultural work
Vegetal hat
carved wooden disc knocked by another piece to which it is tied with a string, used in simbong song
to groan; pasarro-sarroan: name of a drum pattern for funerals or for illness
water spot
downstream
monkey (generic)
small bird with light blue plumage, white neck and breast; G.sp. Unknown

(from sembang ‘to cut across’ and ongan ‘sun shade’), cutting palm leaves in order to create shade while praying and sacrificing chicken [This name refers to one of the first, lowest-level rituals on the side of rising sun]
white sandalwood, sandalwood [Santalum album]
arm motion in badong song ; massendo : to sing badong while moving arms
song, sung tale, sung line, prayer (sometimes syn. dondi' or londe)
widgeon's nest ; mixed chorus during bua' kasalle ceremony
Cat [Felix sylvestris]
‘to take each other’ for 1) quarreling 2) to be together; dipasiala tu gamaranna the voices are harmonious; suara tae' siala the voices are out of tune
to send something reciprocally back and forth (words, sentiments etc.)
kore: to work alternately. Sikore-kore: to alternate sounds with one another (e.g.: when the rice-mortar is struck by several people); used in the pieces suling deata
(lau' step); ordered in steps
(from lopak join together); aluk silopak tallang rule of the bamboos joined together; see aluk pembalikan
hair bun

(Mamasa area) simbong banua: song for praising houses; simbong kura: song for courting. Male and female chorus sing in alternation with a drone; each chorus has a tomarrodo (a leader), a to mangoro (the one who hold the breath), and to marrorodan, tomantoran, tomappadani
(Sa’dan Toraja area) male song in two vocal parts with drone, sung at highest rituals on side of rising sun (usually at bua' kasalle celebration). Manimbong: to sing the simbong
post (tree or stone) for tethering buffaloes before sacrifices; simbuang batu: menhir erected for deceased nobility on field of menhirs
to get married
rhythmic praise declaimed by to minaa officiant in Western (singgi’ to mate) or Eastern rituals (singgi’ bua’)
to hold ; to tense (voices)
chanted into the house during bua' kasalle; one corner is taken by the old people, the second by young people, the third and last by the children, it is a three nights game (Kruyt 1921: 53)
to lap up by sucking ; ( simbong) to up half a step
cockfighting
alternate reciprocally; sisonda menaa to alternate breath in turn, (singing) for one singer to breathe while the other continues to sing
brother, sister
(from sode ‘happy time in a life’); sode-sode: to praise, exalt
moving one's arm
to venerate
to change, to alternate; disonda'i te dondi' ‘change the tune of this dondi'’
filed; (voice) sparkling, clear; gamaranna sontik langi' (bugi'): a voice sparkling to the sky
(voice) to go down disossoran tu gamara
Plucked-lute (see kecapi or katapi)
euphorbia of the ancients (Malayan splurge) [Euphorbia antiquorum]
measure of the ritual, from sukaran ‘measure’
bamboo pipe
to come back; to return, to put upside down (see sumule)
generic term for any bamboo flute; suling deata ‘flutes of gods’
flute pieces for pakorong healing ritual
vital energy, life force

(North Toraja: Makki and Seko) round dance ; (Baruppu') name of popular song accompanied by a guitar ; (Luwu') traditional dance in Desa Walenreng, performed at wedding or house ceremony; solo female dance accompanied by song in Bugis-Luwu'
room at the rear (southern) end of the house
(Salu Mambi area) head hunting song
lower bell-like tip in buffalo horn at the end of a flute (syn. kolok or kolong)
to speak (see kada)
(from sule to come back, to repair, to put upside down); (music) to move from low to high in one octave to tune a flute
to carve; ma'surak tedong, ritual for the buffalo

comb; simple rite of atonement, commonly performed, called rite of the fine-toothed comb or rite of cleansing. To atone for an error, a chicken should be sacrificed and its meat mixed with rice and offered to the divinities and ancestors. The chicken’s feathers are hung up in the home; see sara’ka
breast, milk; ma'pasusu: to dry a coprse by collecting bodily fluids.
cordyline, bloodwort [Cordilyne terminalis]
wasp, hornet, hornet-wasp
k.o. fragrant grass (flax lily?) [Dianella ensifolia]
very loud sound (=lilling)
ear
ringing
k.o. Thin bamboo; G.sp. unknown
to come in ; towards the rising sun (see lan)
to call divinities
heron, Chinese pond heron [Ardeola bacchus, Egretta garzetta]
prayer (bua' kasalle and merok ceremony)
youngest singer at end of simbong or nani line [in former times, such individuals might be slaves]
post to mark a boundary, social class
mushrooms; G.sp. unknown
stick zither, tube zither, (fig. pellet drum)
to listen to
golden horns
forest rat; G.sp. Unknown
front of the house; metangdo': first part of the bua' kasalle
bird; G.sp. Unknown
(lit.) handle of comb; purification ritual in which chicken sacrificed in the house
small bamboos for covering house's front and rear gable
k.o. nightshade, inedible, green or yellow, ressembling eggplant fruit [Solanum melongena]
effigy of dead person
water buffalo (gen.) [Bubalus bubalis]
stick used by female singers of dandan or dondo chorus (bua' kasalle ceremony)
to move from high to low in a dance
to praise
red hawk with white plumage; G.sp. Unknown
parade of men armed with spears preceding manganda’ dancers at bua' kasalle
quarter
hoarse
corner; sangtetuk: a group of soloist in badong; badong ditetuki: badong with four groups of soloists
to be in a line; [ma'tibang is the gelong maro or gelong bugi' when it is sung in a line by women with the men in the back, filmed by Rolf de Maré in 1938]
k. o. sugar cane with leaves as of citronella [Andropopogon nardus] with a soft stalk [Themeda gigantes ? Andropogon Halepensis Stapf ?]
to receive; slow song in the gelong bate, maro ceremonies, Manarangko untimangngi pandeko ussarandekki  You know how to receive
cucumber [Cucumis sativus]
k.o. Tree whose bark used to make rope ; G.sp. unknown
to begin, pa'tindok the one who begins ; ma'tindok: in the badong, vocalist's embellishments
to praise a guest during funerals
decrescendo drumming
shouting of manganda' dancers
female or male officiant of highest order in rites of the rising sun, has the garatung pellet drum as attribute
see kadongi
the one who wraps the body, the death officiant
knowledgeable person, specialist of ritual speech on the sides of rising and setting sun
water buffalo with a white spot on the head

to mark s.o.'s forehead with blood of a sacrificed animal ; blood or earth taken from sacrificial field, applied to forehead as sign of divinities' power to repel maledictions ; gift of money on singers, dancers or instrumentalists
ancestors
organized in layers
to hang
spearing of the waterbuffalo, name for merok ritual
to organize ; tolo' bating :to organize the line of lamentation
ancestor who descended from heaven to live on earth
old ones, ancestors
banner
the one who sing (title of an officiant who perform his eulogy at the bua' kasalle celebration)
village
(tongkon to sit), important house, centre of a family
ono': ordered in layers; tonoranni: to compose by ordering as layers in a roof
blessing (syn. samaya)
bamboo band encircling ricebarn, sign that 24 buffalos have been killed for the funeral of one male inhabitant of the house
to rise, to ascend; rambu tuka' ‘smoke rises’, rites from the Eastern side
short flute; ma' tulali-lali: to whistle
ma'tullik: to whistle
to cry
female effigy decorated with ornaments during the bua’ kasalle (= anak dara)
leaping dance ; woman who enters into trance during maro ritual ; woman obeying series of interdictions during bua' kasalle.
tumba: drumming for divinities, annoucing a disaster ; ma'tumbarakai: to make an offering for divinities after a disaster
rattan [Calamus scipionum]
snake (generic)
strong, powerful; tumangi' umborron-borron : to cry powerfully

snoring, buzzing; unnumbung: to buzz (about bees), to snore; siumbungan: game between two men who sings a note continuously on the letter m without breathing [the first man to breath loses the game. This game was used in older times to settle disputes among two men accusing each other of misdeeds]
to tune the voices together
male song sung while seated during funerals, in the Sa'dan area, unnosong
shrimp (generic)
k.o small tree, with large round leaves; G.sp. Unknown
k. o. wood for house building [Michelia celebica]
